item.title: Bitcoin verstehen â€“ Episode 297 - Kritiker sagen: Bitcoin wird sterben - Wann kommt der Crash?
item.description:
In dieser Folge nehmen wir euch mit hinter die Kulissen und reagieren auf E-Mails, Kommentare und Feedback aus unserer Community. Von liebevoller Kritik bis zu harten Vorwürfen ist alles dabei: Sind wir „Gen-Z-Vollidioten“, geldgierige Dummköpfe oder Teil einer Bitcoin-Sekte?

Wir sprechen darüber, ob wir Themen ernst genug behandeln, ob Regulatorik die Nutzung von Bitcoin erschwert und warum sich am Ende doch immer alles um den Preis zu drehen scheint. Außerdem geht’s um den Vergleich Gold vs. Bitcoin und die Frage, ob wir mit dem, was wir sagen, falsche Versprechungen machen.

item.title: The Bitcoin Frontier â€“ Venture on a bitcoin standard with Allen Farrington
item.description:
Allen Farrington is an investor at Axiom BTC Capital and a writer known for sharp, contrarian takes on bitcoin and adjacent topics like bitcoin venture capital, fiat â€œplumbing,â€ and stablecoins. With Axiom, Allen uniquely focuses on clientsâ€™ returns not coming from financial engineering, but from productive deployment of capital to solve real world problems.

In this episode, Allen joins The Bitcoin Frontier to share how bitcoin exposes the fiat distortions inside venture capital, why clear lines between saving and investing change founder and limited partner (LP) behavior, and what a bitcoin-first stack means for payments and stablecoins. We dig into local capital allocation on a sound-money standard, free/open-source dynamics and moats, and why lightning + ecash may be the endgame for stablecoins.

item.title: The Mustard Seedâ€”a bitcoin and long-term thinking podcast â€“ The Next Liquidity Wave Will Look Completely Different w/ Peter Dunworth
item.description:
Bitcoin did not rally in 2025, yet the foundations for the next decade were laid quietly and decisively. This conversation breaks down why ETFs ended the four-year cycle, how the global collateral crisis points toward bitcoin, and why AI-driven abundance makes fixed digital scarcity more valuable over time. It is a long-term, low-time preference discussion on where capital ultimately settles when incentives, regulation, and technology align.

item.title: Blockspace: A Bitcoin Podcast â€“ TECH: How Bitcoin engineers are solving the quantum risk
item.description:
Tackling the technical battle to protect Bitcoin from quantum computers. We explore why quantum-resistant signatures are up to 100x larger than current ones and the impact this has on block space and fees. From lattice-based math to STARK-based compression, Charlie breaks down the leading proposals like BIP 360 and BIP 347. We also calculate the "migration" timelineâ€”how long it would actually take to move every Bitcoin to a safe address before "Q-Day" arrives.


Subscribe to the newsletter! https://newsletter.blockspacemedia.com


Notes:

* Quantum signatures can reach 17,000 bytes (500x!)

* Optimized hash signatures are 50x larger.

* Full BTC migration takes 76 to 142 days.

* There are 190 million unspent BTC outputs.

item.title: Rob Wallace | Bitcoin News â€“ Satoshiâ€™s Coins at Risk: Quantum Computers Could Steal 30% of BTC | Charles Edwards
item.description:
Is Bitcoin facing an existential crisis? Rob Wallace sits down with Charles Edwards, founder of Capriole Investments, to discuss the 2026 outlook for Bitcoin and the broader macro markets.

Following a major technical breakout above $93,500, Charles explains how an $11 trillion surge in global money supply is fueling the next leg up for risk assets.

However, the conversation takes a serious turn as they discuss "Q-Day," the day quantum computers could potentially break Bitcoin's encryption. With a 20-30% probability of this occurring by 2028, Charles lays out the urgent roadmap for BIP 360 and the philosophical battle over whether to "burn" or "hack" Satoshiâ€™s 1.1 million coins.

item.title: Stephan Livera Podcast â€“ Hash-based signatures for Bitcoin's post-quantum future? with Jonas Nick | SLP713
item.description:
In this conversation, Stephan Livera and Jonas Nick discuss the implications of quantum computing on Bitcoin's security, focusing on the risks posed to cryptographic signatures. They explore the current vulnerabilities in Bitcoin, the potential for quantum attacks, and the need for post-quantum cryptographic solutions. The discussion covers various signature schemes, including hash-based signatures, their trade-offs, and the challenges of transitioning to a quantum-resistant Bitcoin. They also touch on the implications for hardware wallets, multi-signature schemes, and the potential need for block size increases to accommodate new signature sizes.

Takeaways:

ğŸ”¸Quantum computers pose a real risk to Bitcoin's cryptography.

ğŸ”¸Current Bitcoin signatures are vulnerable to long-range attacks.

ğŸ”¸Hash-based signatures are significantly larger than current signatures.

ğŸ”¸Transitioning to quantum resistance will require careful planning.

ğŸ”¸The Bitcoin community must reach a consensus on new schemes.

ğŸ”¸Verification costs will increase with new signature schemes.

ğŸ”¸Hardware wallets will need to adapt to new signature requirements.

ğŸ”¸Block size discussions may need to be revisited in light of quantum risks.

ğŸ”¸The timeline for quantum computing advancements is uncertain.

ğŸ”¸A gradual transition to quantum resistance may be necessary.Â 

Timestamps:

(00:00) - Intro

(38:50) - What are Adaptor signatures & how do they affect atomic swapping?Â 

(41:27) - Will we need new Bitcoin hardware wallets?; Signature production & verificationÂ 

(44:41) - Signature size and Bitcoin block capacity implications

(46:52) - Should we revisit the block size conversation?Â 

(54:57) - Overview of SPHINCS+ & SHRINCS

(59:49) - Transitioning to post-quantum signature schemes; Overview of BIP 360

(1:09:06) - Closing thoughts

Davidson argues that Bitcoin provides a durable path toward financial stability, technological leadership, and renewed economic freedom for the American people.Key topics covered:â€¢ Bitcoin tax reform and de minimis payment exemptionsâ€¢ National competitiveness in the digital asset economyâ€¢ Inflation, fiscal policy, and sovereign savings strategyâ€¢ CBDC risks and the importance of privacy-preserving moneyâ€¢ Gen Z financial opportunity and long-term savingsFor viewers interested in Bitcoin policy, economic strategy, and Americaâ€™s financial future, this discussion offers essential insight into how forward-looking legislation could shape the decades ahead.Contact your elected representatives and encourage support for the Bitcoin for America Act.Subscribe for more policy-focused interviews and expert research from the Bitcoin Policy Institute.

item.title: Einfach Bitcoin Podcast â€“ Wie funktioniert eine Bitcoin-Adresse
item.description:
---werbung---
N26 ist ein kostenloses, mobiles Konto, das du in wenigen Minuten erÃ¶ffnest â€“ mit der MÃ¶glichkeit, Finanzprodukte und Krypto zu kaufen, Rechnungen mÃ¼helos mit Freunden zu teilen und sogar PrÃ¤mien zu erhalten, wenn du andere einlÃ¤dst. Wenn du ein Konto suchst, das dir dein Finanzleben wirklich erleichtert, ist jetzt der perfekte Moment, einzusteigen.
        JETZT KOSTENLOS ANMELDEN!
---werbung---
 Bitcoin hat in den letzten Jahren Millionen von Menschen fasziniert. Ob als digitales Zahlungsmittel, Wertanlage oder technologische Revolution â€“ die erste KryptowÃ¤hrung der Welt verÃ¤ndert, wie wir Ã¼ber Geld denken. Doch wer das erste Mal mit Bitcoin zu tun hat, stÃ¶ÃŸt schnell auf einen Begriff, der alles andere als selbsterklÃ¤rend ist: die Bitcoin-Adresse. Was ist sie genau, wie entsteht sie, und warum ist sie so wichtig fÃ¼r die Sicherheit und AnonymitÃ¤t des Bitcoin-Systems? 

Um diese Fragen zu verstehen, mÃ¼ssen wir einen Blick hinter die Kulissen werfen â€“ in die Welt der Kryptografie, Hashfunktionen und digitalen SchlÃ¼ssel. Denn die Bitcoin-Adresse ist nicht einfach eine â€Kontonummerâ€œ, sondern das Ergebnis einer komplexen mathematischen Struktur, die Vertrauen ohne zentrale Instanz ermÃ¶glicht. 

 
Was ist eine Bitcoin-Adresse eigentlich? 

Eine Bitcoin-Adresse ist das digitale Pendant zu einer Kontonummer â€“ aber viel sicherer, dezentraler und anonymer. Sie ist eine Zeichenfolge aus Buchstaben und Zahlen, die mit einer bestimmten Ziffernfolge beginnt, zum Beispiel mit einer 1, 3 oder bc1. Diese Zeichenfolge reprÃ¤sentiert den Ã¶ffentlichen Teil eines kryptografischen SchlÃ¼sselpaares und dient dazu, Bitcoin zu empfangen. 

Im Gegensatz zu einem Bankkonto steht hinter einer Bitcoin-Adresse kein Name, keine IdentitÃ¤t und keine Bank. Stattdessen basiert sie vollstÃ¤ndig auf Mathematik. Jeder kann in Sekundenschnelle eine neue Adresse generieren â€“ kostenlos und ohne Registrierung. Die Adresse selbst wird aus einem Public Key abgeleitet, der wiederum aus einem Private Key entsteht. Nur der Besitzer des Private Keys kann Ã¼ber die Bitcoins verfÃ¼gen, die auf eine bestimmte Adresse gesendet wurden. 

Dieses System macht Bitcoin so einzigartig: Es gibt keine zentrale Datenbank, die Eigentum verwaltet. Stattdessen basiert alles auf Kryptografie und Ã¶ffentlicher Transparenz. 

 
Wie entsteht eine Bitcoin-Adresse technisch? 

Hinter einer scheinbar zufÃ¤lligen Zeichenkette verbirgt sich ein raffinierter Prozess. Eine Bitcoin-Adresse entsteht durch eine Abfolge kryptografischer Schritte, die dafÃ¼r sorgen, dass sie sowohl einzigartig als auch sicher ist. 

Alles beginnt mit einem zufÃ¤llig generierten Private Key. Dieser SchlÃ¼ssel ist eine 256-Bit-Zahl â€“ also eine extrem groÃŸe Zahl, die fast unmÃ¶glich zu erraten ist. Aus diesem Private Key wird mithilfe der elliptischen Kurvenkryptografie der Public Key berechnet. Das Besondere: Man kann aus dem Private Key den Public Key erzeugen, aber nicht umgekehrt. Das garantiert, dass der Private Key geheim bleibt. 

AnschlieÃŸend wird der Public Key mehrfach mit kryptografischen Hashfunktionen (SHA-256 und RIPEMD-160) verarbeitet. Diese Schritte verdichten und anonymisieren die Daten, bis am Ende eine eindeutige, 26â€“35 Zeichen lange Bitcoin-Adresse entsteht. 

Um Tippfehler zu vermeiden und die Ãœbertragbarkeit zu verbessern, verwendet das Bitcoin-Protokoll ein spezielles Base58Check-Format. Es verzichtet auf leicht verwechselbare Zeichen wie 0, O, l und I und fÃ¼gt eine PrÃ¼fsumme hinzu. So wird sichergestellt, dass eine falsch eingegebene Adresse sofort als ungÃ¼ltig erkannt wird. 

Das gesamte System basiert auf offenen, Ã¼berprÃ¼fbaren mathematischen Prinzipien â€“ und genau das macht Bitcoin so vertrauenswÃ¼rdig. Niemand muss â€glaubenâ€œ, dass eine Adresse echt ist. Jeder kann es mathematisch Ã¼berprÃ¼fen. 

 
Die Rolle von Public und Private Key â€“ das Herz der Sicherheit 

Die Sicherheit einer Bitcoin-Adresse hÃ¤ngt vollstÃ¤ndig vom VerhÃ¤ltnis zwischen Public Key und Private Key ab. Der Public Key ist wie eine Ã¶ffentliche Briefkastenadresse: Jeder kann dorthin â€Postâ€œ schicken, also Bitcoin senden. Der Private Key hingegen ist der einzige SchlÃ¼ssel, um diesen Briefkasten zu Ã¶ffnen â€“ sprich: um die Bitcoins wieder auszugeben. 

Wer seinen Private Key verliert, verliert unwiderruflich den Zugriff auf die Coins. Das ist einer der grÃ¶ÃŸten Unterschiede zum traditionellen Bankwesen: Es gibt keinen â€Passwort-Resetâ€œ oder Kundendienst, der helfen kann. Deshalb speichern viele Nutzer ihre privaten SchlÃ¼ssel auf sogenannten Hardware Wallets, die offline sind und so vor Hackerangriffen geschÃ¼tzt werden. 

Ein Private Key ist mathematisch einzigartig. Die Wahrscheinlichkeit, dass zwei Personen zufÃ¤llig denselben Private Key erzeugen, ist astronomisch gering â€“ so gering, dass es praktisch ausgeschlossen ist. Das macht das Bitcoin-Netzwerk sicher, ohne dass eine zentrale BehÃ¶rde eingreifen muss. 

In modernen Wallets werden die SchlÃ¼ssel meist nicht einzeln verwaltet, sondern mithilfe eines Seeds oder einer mnemonischen Wortliste erzeugt. Diese 12 oder 24 WÃ¶rter ermÃ¶glichen die Wiederherstellung aller zugehÃ¶rigen Bitcoin-Adressen. 

Die perfekte Symbiose aus Kryptografie, Mathematik und dezentraler Logik sorgt dafÃ¼r, dass niemand deine Bitcoins kontrollieren kann â€“ auÃŸer du selbst. 

 
Unterschiedliche Adressformate: Legacy, SegWit und Bech32 

Im Laufe der Bitcoin-Entwicklung haben sich verschiedene Adressformate etabliert, die unterschiedliche technische HintergrÃ¼nde haben. Die Ã¤lteste Form sind Legacy-Adressen, die mit einer â€1â€œ beginnen. Sie stammen aus der Anfangszeit des Netzwerks und sind mit allen Ã¤lteren Wallets kompatibel.

item.title: Bitcoiners - Live From Bitcoin Beach â€“ How El Salvador Forced This Crypto Billionaire to Use Bitcoin (Proof The Circular Economy Works)
item.description:
Can a rural village in El Salvador actually replace the central bank?

Host Jethro Toro hangs out with Mike Peterson and the founders of Bitcoin Berlin, Evelyn Lemus and Gerardo Linares. They talk about a grassroots movement that is changing how people use money. We explore the true story of El Zonte, where a project focused on community development built a true circular economy. They used the Lightning Network to make fast digital payments just to survive the pandemic proving the experts wrong years before big banks caught on.

Evelyn and Gerardo explain exactly how they got a whole town excited about Bitcoin without asking the government for permission. We follow their journey from the coast to the mountains of Berlin. They are teaching high school students about decentralized finance so they can run their own independent systems instead of trusting apps to hold their money. They also highlight how El Salvador tourism is booming as Bitcoin fans visit to support local shop owners who are saving in Bitcoin.

We also look at how they are fighting back against expensive money transfer companies. You will learn how a new project in La Laguna uses a local hardware store to help families send money home without paying Western Union's high fees. The team explains why they stopped using the government's Chivo wallet to use better open tools. They even share a new guide for anyone who wants to start a Bitcoin community in their own neighborhood.

Subscribe to the channel to see the proof that this works, and leave a comment if you are ready to try a new way of using money.

item.title: Bitcoin Audible â€“ Chat_158 - Is The Bitcoin Mission Fading? with Stephan Livera
item.description:
"Of course, central banking, fiat money is bad, but nevertheless, maybe AI and robotics and this productivity is going to be really beneficial to the global economy, not just the U.S. economy.

We're going to start to see the liquidity, the whole U.S. PMI go up, and that's going to cause Bitcoin NGU. That's kind of how I'm seeing this next year or two.

I think we're going to see a lot of AI, productivity and extra liquidity coming in. So I am very bullish on this coming year."

~ Stephan Livera

The Bitcoin landscape has changed dramatically over the last few years, leading many to ask: is the cypherpunk ethos fading away?

I sit down with the legendary podcaster Stephan Livera to explore the tension between ideological purity and the pragmatic reality of global adoption. We dive deep into the "Power Law" of Bitcoin's growth, why our timeframes might be all wrong, and the controversial role of stablecoins as a stepping stone. From the mechanics of Spark and Ark to the arbitrage strategies of treasury companies, we cover how the ecosystem is evolving to meet the world where it is. Are we losing our way, or simply maturing into the financial system of the future?

item.title: Bitcoin, Fiat & Rock'n'Roll â€“ Industry Expert Outlooks for 2026 with Blockstories
item.description:
In this special 2026 predictions episode, host Alex is joined by Stefan (ZÃ¼hlke) and Maximilian Vargas (Blockstories) for a forward-looking discussion based on Blockstoriesâ€™ new report: â€œ25 Predictions from 25 Digital Asset Expertsâ€.

Instead of presenting their own forecasts, the trio picks standout expert takes across five key themesâ€”tokenization, digital money, regulation, markets & investments, and infrastructureâ€”and pressure-tests them from a pragmatic, institution-first perspective.

A central debate: tokenized deposits vs. stablecoins. Stefan challenges the idea that tokenized deposits will â€œgo through the roofâ€ in 2026, arguing that market pull may favor stablecoins, yield-bearing stablecoins, and tokenized money market funds, especially in a world increasingly obsessed with yield. Max adds a crucial banking reality check: many banks still view stablecoin enablement as partly defensiveâ€”driven by corporate treasurers expecting 24/7 money movementâ€”while tokenized deposits feel more compatible with existing models (and balance sheet logic). Alex highlights the strategic dilemma: banks may need to integrate stablecoins even though doing so could accelerate deposit flight.

The conversation broadens into the â€œunbundling vs. rebundlingâ€ of financial servicesâ€”particularly how stablecoins and on-chain products could fragment banking value chains, and whether banks can reclaim the â€œorchestratorâ€ role across rails (stablecoins, tokenized deposits, CBDCs, e-money) while keeping client ownership.

A major DeFi thread emerges around on-chain vaults: smart-contract-based â€œdepotsâ€ that package strategies and yield. The guests explore why vaults could become a breakout distribution mechanism for stablecoinsâ€”and potentially a disruptive force for traditional asset management as â€œvault curationâ€ grows into a new layer of financial intermediation.

Other highlighted themes include the rise of tokenized equities (with a narrative flip: liquid assets may tokenize before illiquid ones), the push toward core infrastructure integration inside institutions (production > experimentation), and why privacy could shift from â€œnice-to-haveâ€ to â€œinstitutional requirementâ€â€”even if scalability trade-offs remain unresolved.

The episode closes with a lively macro riff: is the classic four-year crypto cycle ending, and will institutional allocators (even Ivy League endowments) meaningfully increase crypto exposure by end-2026? As always: not investment adviceâ€”just a sharp, insider-grade map of what might shape the next phase of digital finance.

item.title: Thank God for Bitcoin â€“ Episode 74 The End of The Beginning of TGFB
item.description:
In this episode of the TGFB podcast, hosts Jordan Bush and Ahshuwah Hawthorne discuss the transition of TGFB to a nonprofit organization. They explore the challenges faced as a for-profit entity, the importance of serving the Christian Bitcoin community, and the collaboration with Brilliance Labs to enhance their mission. The conversation also covers the logistics of donations and the future vision for TGFB, emphasizing the need for community support and engagement.

You can read Jordan's summary here: https://economicsofglory.substack.com/p/a-new-era-for-thank-god-for-bitcoin?r=ep83x

And you can donate to support TGFB's work via Brilliance Labs here: http://brilliancelabs.org/tgfb

]]>

item.title: VERIFIED by Bitcoin Suisse â€“ Crypto Outlook 2026
item.description:
In this episode of the Verified Podcast by Bitcoin Suisse, Dominic Weibel sits down with investment strategist DenisÂ Oevermann, crypto market analyst LucaÂ Gnos, and junior portfolio manager Mateo Sansonetti to dissect crypto's performance in 2025 and share their predictions for 2026.Â 
Â 
The discussion examines why 2025 was a year where crypto overdelivered on fundamentals but underdelivered on price. The panel explores new regulatory frameworks, the pro-crypto stance of the U.S. administration, and the disjointed performance between Bitcoin and altcoins. They analyze the explosive growth of options trading, the rise of prediction markets, and how macroeconomic factors and institutional flows will shape 2026.Â 
Â 
The conversation also tackles AI's market influence, the potential for Federal Reserve rate cuts, retail sentiment versus institutional positioning, and price predictions for Bitcoin and Ethereum heading into the new year.

item.title: Epicenter - Learn about Crypto, Blockchain, Ethereum, Bitcoin and Distributed Technologies â€“ Buidl Europe 2026: The State of Decentralization
item.description:
In this episode, recorded live at Buidl Europe 2026, host Sebastian Couture leads a panel with Ben Lakoff (Bankless Ventures), Richard Muirhead (Fabric Ventures), Aurora Orellana (G20 Strategies), and Matthew Arrow (Dark Forest). Together, they tackle the existential question facing the industry: can Cypherpunk values like self-custody and permissionless survive as multi-billion dollar institutions become the primary drivers of adoption?



The discussion delves into the tension between individual sovereignty and the regulatory reach of organizations like the FATF, which they describe as a "Goliath" accountable to no one. They explore the concept of the "DeFi Mullet" a centralized user interfaces powered by decentralized backends and how privacyÂ tech isÂ becoming essential not for institutions seeking defensible competitive moats. Finally, the conversation looks at how global competition between jurisdictions will define the next decade of financial freedom and what it truly means to be a Cypherpunk in 2026.Â 




Topics

  • 00:00 Intro & Context
  • 04:15 Cypherpunk Values in an Institutional World
  • 09:30 Permissionless Deployment & Self-Custody
  • 15:00 The Regulatory Spectrum: KYC vs. Freedom
  • 21:45 The FATF & Global Financial Surveillance
  • 27:10 Jurisdictional Competition & Portability
  • 35:20 Selling Privacy to Institutions vs. Individuals
  • 42:15 The DeFi Mullet & Atomic Settlement
  • 49:00 Barriers to Entry: Legacy Mainframes & Career Risk
  • 55:30 What it Means to be a Cypherpunk in 2026
